question: What resource supplies plants with the minerals they need to grow?

content.source_1: [Plants require mineral nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium to grow and complete their life cycles.]
content.source_2: [Soils contain and supply mineral nutrients to plants, derived from weathered rock and decomposed organic matter.]
content.source_3: [In terrestrial environments, soil is the primary reservoir from which plants obtain mineral nutrients.]
content.source_4: [Plant roots take up mineral nutrients only as dissolved ions from the soil solution—the water in soil pore spaces—rather than from solid soil particles.]
content.source_5: [Water acts as the solvent and carrier that transports dissolved mineral ions into roots and upward through the plant via the xylem.]
content.source_6: [Mineral nutrients bound to soil particles must first dissolve into the soil water before plants can absorb them.]
